;根据国土安全部的记录，美国总统乔·拜登的狗 Commander 在 2022 年 10 月至 1 月期间咬伤或以其他方式攻击特勤局人员至少 10 次，其中一次事件需要受伤执法人员前往医院。

;

;保守派监督组织司法观察周二公布了通过《信息自由法》诉讼获得的近 200 页特勤局记录。

;

;该组织表示，在国土安全部下属机构去年 12 月要求提供涉及纯种德国牧羊犬的咬伤事件记录后，该机构“未能做出充分回应”，因此提起诉讼。该组织表示，在收到有关 Commander 行为的举报后提出了请求。

;

;Commander 是拜登的第二只表现出攻击性的狗，包括咬伤特勤人员和白宫工作人员。这些事件发生后，他们最终将这只名叫梅杰的德国牧羊犬送到特拉华州与朋友住在一起。

;

;周二，白宫和特勤局似乎淡化了这一情况，但最新的事件引发了人们的疑问：为什么拜登一家将另一只德国牧羊犬带到行政官邸，以及为什么袭击仍在继续。

;

;第一夫人吉尔·拜登的通讯总监伊丽莎白·亚历山大在一封电子邮件中表示，对于家庭宠物来说，白宫建筑群是一个“独特且经常充满压力的环境”。拜登家族正在“想方设法让这种情况对每个人都更好”。

;

;特勤局首席发言人安东尼·古列尔米(Anthony Guglielmi)在另一封电子邮件中表示，特勤局过去几任总统“都在探讨如何最好地处理家庭宠物问题，这些事件也不例外。我们非常重视员工的安全和福祉。”

;

;特勤局为总统及其家人提供安全保护，数十名官员驻扎在行政官邸及其广阔的场地周围。

;

;第一只猫：拜登夫妇欢迎威洛猫入主白宫

;

;拜登于 2021 年 12 月收到了指挥官作为他兄弟詹姆斯的礼物。这家人还养了一只猫，名为 Willow。

;

;2022 年 11 月 3 日，一名特勤局官员向同事发送电子邮件称，指挥官咬了一名穿制服的警官两次——右上臂和大腿。白宫医疗部门的工作人员对这名警官进行了治疗，并决定将该人送往医院。

;

;制服部门的一名队长当天晚些时候通过电子邮件表示，他已被告知指挥官已接种最新疫苗。

;

;第二天的一条说明添加了有关此次袭击的详细信息，包括被咬伤的警官使用一辆钢车来保护自己免受另一次袭击。随后，根据医生的建议，这名警官被安排执行几天的限制性职务。

;

;亚历山大表示，拜登夫妇一直在与特勤局和白宫官邸工作人员合作，为指挥官“制定额外的牵引协议和培训”，并建立指定区域供指挥官跑步锻炼。

;

;“总统和第一夫人非常感谢特勤局和行政官邸工作人员为保护他们、家人和国家安全所做的一切，”亚历山大补充道。

;

;古格里尔mi 表示，鼓励特勤局员工向其直接主管报告与工作有关的伤害，以获取适当的文件。

;

;“因此，我们了解过去涉及第一家庭宠物的事件，这些事件的处理方式与类似的工作场所伤害类似，包括相关通知和遵循的报告程序，”他说。

;

;乔和吉尔·拜登哀悼失去他们的宠物德国牧羊犬 Champ

;

;“而特工和官员既不关心也不处理第一家庭的宠物Guglielmi 补充道：“我们不断与所有相关实体合作，尽量减少宠物环境中的不利影响。”

;

;指挥官经常被白宫首席场地管理员牵着走。

;

;《纽约邮报》最先报道了指挥官咬人事件。

;周二，一架希腊空军洒水飞机在希腊南部的一场野火中坠毁，两名飞行员丧生，当时当局正在与热浪气温回升导致全国肆虐数日的大火作斗争。

;

;国家 ERT 电视视频显示，这架 CL-215 飞机在埃维亚岛释放了水，然后其翼尖显然被树枝卡住了。片刻之后，它消失在地面深处的一个褶皱中，并从其中喷发出一个火球。

;

;空军表示，年龄分别为 34 岁和 27 岁的飞行员均在坠机事故中丧生。这架飞机没有弹射系统。

;

;希腊总理基里亚科斯·米佐塔基斯取消了周三访问塞浦路斯的计划，并要求希腊武装部队哀悼三天。

;

;周二，希腊连续第三次热浪导致该国部分地区气温回升至 40 摄氏度（104 华氏度）以上。 .

;

;目前还不清楚它们是如何开始的，尽管夏季炎热的干燥环境意味着最轻微的火花都可能引发大火，如果不迅速扑灭，大火就会迅速蔓延。最近几天，希腊各地已有多人因意外起火而被捕或被罚款。

;

;“人间地狱”：希腊与火灾“交战”，数千人被疏散

;

;希腊消防局发言人表示，周二最严重的火灾发生在东南部的罗德岛和西北部的科孚岛，这两个岛屿都是热门的旅游目的地。

;

;“在其他方面，我们必须处理许多起火的情况。 Ioannis Artopios 说。

;

;周二，罗得岛的四个村庄被命令疏散，因为燃烧了八天的大火继续向内陆蔓延，烧毁了山区森林地区，包括自然保护区的一部分。科孚岛又下令进行五次疏散，埃维亚岛也进行了一夜疏散。

;

;在罗德岛，绝望的居民用铲子扑灭逼近自家的火焰，许多人脖子上挂着湿毛巾来躲避酷热，而消防飞机和直升机则在黎明时分恢复了水滴。

;

;“第十二天，在极端炎热和强风的条件下，我们正在不间断地扑灭数十起森林火灾。战线。 ......希腊消防局已经扑灭了 500 多起火灾，每天超过 50 起，”气候危机和民防部长瓦西利斯·基基利亚斯 (Vassilis Kikilias) 表示。

;

;当局表示，岛上已有 20,000 多人参与了连续疏散，其中大部分是周末大火席卷罗德岛东南部两个沿海地区的游客。

;

;欧盟已派出 500 名消防员，其中 10 名是消防员。来自10个成员国的0辆汽车和7架飞机，同时土耳其、以色列、埃及等国也派出了援助。贡献国家包括正在应对国内火灾和极端天气的意大利。

;

;夏季野火也袭击了其他地中海国家，导致阿尔及利亚至少 34 人死亡。

;

;欧盟官员将欧洲大陆野火频率和强度不断增加归咎于气候变化，并指出 2022 年是继 2017 年之后有记录以来野火损失第二严重的一年。

;

;在西西岛随着山火逼近，巴勒莫国际机场暂时关闭。但在意大利北部伦巴第地区，一场强大的风暴引发了洪水、停电，并导致一名 16 岁女孩在童子军营地死亡。

;

;在土耳其，作为预防措施，土耳其安塔利亚省地中海度假胜地凯梅尔附近的一片崎岖森林地区发生野火，当局于周二疏散了十几所房屋和一家医院。

;

;西部马尼萨省爆发的另一场野火已得到控制一天后，火势到达一个小村庄，烧毁了至少 14 所房屋。所有居民均已疏散，无人受伤。

;

;在雅典，当局恢复了古卫城下午的关闭时间，作为应对高温的更广泛措施的一部分。

;“我们正在慢慢取得进展，因为关键是菲律宾政府与中国政府之间改善沟通，”小费迪南德·马科斯总统在南海有争议的渔业资源最新谈判后表示。

;

;就在几天前，菲律宾还接待了一支中国人民解放军海军特遣队的友好访问。中国驻马尼拉大使馆称此次海军访问是“（双边）防务合作的坚实一步”，对于“落实两国领导人的重要共识”至关重要。最近，中国高级外交官王毅表示，中国已准备好与菲律宾开启“新黄金时代”。

;

;小马科斯强调了强有力的沟通渠道在管理与中国海上争端方面的重要性。这符合他在选举时期的誓言，即在与菲律宾最大贸易伙伴打交道时优先考虑对话而不是对抗。然而，由于美国在这个东南亚国家的军事存在问题上日益增长的分歧，中美关系取得丰硕成果的希望被削弱了。

;

;特别是，小马科斯决定实施甚至扩大有争议的《增强防务合作协议》(EDCA)，该协议允许五角大楼使用菲律宾珍贵的军事设施，这一决定引起了北京和包括前总统罗德里戈·杜特尔特在内的菲律宾关键人物的批评。处理与中国日益有争议的关系将是小马科斯上任第二年面临的最大政策挑战之一。

;

;小马科斯是这位前菲律宾强人的同名儿子，刚上台后就立即“重新引入”他的国家，并恢复了臭名昭著的家族的政治声誉。他重新调整了前任的暴力“反毒战争”，转而采取更加注重康复的方式，同时对自由派媒体采取了更加和解的语气。他在第一年还访问了许多国家和合作伙伴，并出席了在瑞士举行的世界经济论坛。

;

;然而，他最重要的举动是在外交政策方面。今年早些时候发布的一项权威调查显示，超过80%的菲律宾人希望该国与传统盟友发展更牢固的关系，以保护其南海利益。小马科斯当选后不久发布的另一项调查显示，美国、澳大利亚和日本是菲律宾人最值得信赖的外国伙伴。相比之下，中国在很大程度上受到了不信任。

;

;为了顺应民意，小马科斯迅速恢复了与传统西方盟友（尤其是美国）的关系。他还在海事争端问题上采取了更加不妥协的立场，并就尚未完成的大型基础设施项目向中国施压。然而，当他突然加强与美国的防务合作，最终在北京访问几周后扩大了 EDCA 协议时，事情就到了紧要关头。

;

;根据防务协议，五角大楼被允许进入具有战略意义的地点，包括靠近南中国海和台湾南部海岸的几个地点。在去年 5 月访问五角大楼期间，小马科斯还监督了旨在增强联合威慑能力的新国防指导方针的签署，其中明确考虑到了中国。

;

;但正是在这一点上，小马科斯的战略矛盾心理开始显现。在访问华盛顿之前不久以及访问华盛顿期间，他至少有两次发誓要确保 EDCA 站点不会被用于针对中国的“进攻”目的。这与菲律宾军方的说法相矛盾，菲律宾军方表示，EDCA 基地可用于紧急情况下的联合行动。

;

;马尼拉的不同声明暴露了深刻的战略矛盾和政治焦虑。这解释了为什么小马科斯政府尚未最终确定 EDCA 的精确轮廓，即轮流驻扎的美军数量和部署的武器系统类型。

;

;首先，国内政治因素在发挥作用。近几个月来，执政联盟内部爆发了公开争吵。前总统、国会女议员格洛丽亚·马卡帕加尔·阿罗约最近被降职。不久之后，副总统萨拉·杜特尔特退出执政党以示抗议。

;

;除了内部权力斗争之外，紧张局势的一个主要领域是阿罗约对小马科斯外交政策的疑虑。阿罗约和杜特尔特家族一直是与北京加强关系的主要倡导者，经常与华盛顿保持一定距离。

;

;前总统杜特尔特也加大了赌注，警告说 EDCA 可能会将菲律宾拖入美中核摊牌。似乎这还不够，他上周访问了北京，会见了国家主席习近平。无论此行是否与菲律宾政府协调，这似乎都是对小马科斯对华日益强硬立场的直接挑战。

;

;对外，小马科斯也面临着重大困境。在他上任的第一年里，他将中国视为不可或缺的发展伙伴，特别是在基础设施方面。但他的 EDCA 政策引起了北京的愤怒。

;

;中国外交官警告马尼拉不要“火上浇油”，而中国海上力量近几个月来加强了在菲律宾声称拥有主权的水域的存在。因此，小马科斯面临着中国投资的潜在损失以及南海直接对抗的前景。

;

;目前尚不清楚小马科斯从美国获得了哪些保证。但显而易见的是，在试图重新平衡外交关系、追随民意并恢复家族形象的过程中，他可能会陷入危险的地缘政治陷阱，并产生巨大的国内政治影响。

;

;处理好与中国的关系并巧妙地校准 EDCA 问题不仅对小马科斯的外交政策成功至关重要，而且对他在国内的政治地位也至关重要。这将是一个艰难的平衡行为。

;组织者周二表示，香港一年一度的书展今年恢复到了疫情爆发前的状态，参加者人数达到近 100 万人，狂热的读者纷纷前往书展，希望能抢到最后一刻的便宜货。

;The United States' economy is on a “very narrow path” to avoiding a recession, the International Monetary Fund's chief economist says, while warning of risks to China's strong post-pandemic recovery.

;

;“A recession is not in our baseline,” Pierre-Olivier Gourinchas said during an interview at the IMF's headquarters in Washington, ahead of the publication of its updated global growth projections on Tuesday.

;

;“We are cautiously prudent that the US economy could avoid a recession and, you know, glide towards its inflation target without having a recession in its future”, he said. “But it's a very, very narrow path”, he warned.

;

;On Tuesday morning, the IMF raised its forecast for global growth in 2023 to 3.0 per cent, up 0.2 percentage points from its previous forecast in April, citing resilient service sector activity in the first quarter of the year.

;

;Top IMF official slams US government over debt stand-off 'anxiety'

;

;The IMF still expects much of the growth this year and next to come from emerging and developing economies, with countries like the United States, Germany and Japan due to grow at a much slower pace than China and India.

;

;But the IMF report also noted there are growing risks to China's economy following its post-pandemic reopening, especially in its troubled real estate sector.

;

;The IMF continues to predict that China's economy will grow by 5.2 per cent this year, up sharply from last year.

;

;But there are now signs that China's rapid economic rebound from the Covid-19 pandemic could be “weakening faster than maybe was anticipated”, Gourinchas said, while noting “some concerns about the strength of the Chinese economy going forward”.

;

;“Maybe there's still a certain amount of slack in the Chinese economy that is not going away and that is weighing on prices,” he said.

;

;This slack has had a positive impact on the global inflation outlook: The IMF now forecasts consumer price increases will slow from 8.7 per cent in 2022 to 6.8 per cent this year, due largely to the decline in Chinese inflation.

;

;But while it may be good news for the global economy, it could pose challenges for Chinese policymakers, Gourinchas said.

;

;“It might require some stronger policies by the Chinese authorities both in terms of monetary policy – maybe a little bit more supportive easing monetary policy – and also in terms of fiscal policy,” he said.

; Tue, 25 Jul 2023 23:20:02 +0800 China replaces Qin Gang with Wang Yi but big political questions lingerhttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3228906/china-replaces-qin-gang-wang-yi-big-political-questions-linger?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.25 23:03;
;;

;China has replaced its foreign minister Qin Gang with his predecessor Wang Yi in an unprecedented move that leaves more questions than answers to one of the most engrossing political dramas in recent years.

;

;Citing a decision by the nation's top legislation body, state media said simply on Tuesday that Qin, who disappeared from the public view in June, was removed from his position.

;

;The reports did not elaborate or say what will happen to the former senior diplomat or his other responsibilities.

;

;Qin, who was promoted by Chinese President Xi Jinping just seven months ago, is also a state councillor and a member of the ruling Communist Party's Central Committee.

;

;While he is now most likely to lose these positions as well, there was no mention of them in Tuesday's terse statement, leaving the public guessing as to the cause of this abrupt change.

;

;Equally puzzling was his replacement. Instead of promoting another candidate, the leadership passed the position to Wang, who was promoted to the powerful Politburo just months ago and was a rank higher than Qin.

;

;This makes Wang one of the most powerful foreign ministers in decades and the first Politburo member since Qian Qichen to hold the position – which is mainly responsible for policy implementation. Qian was both China's foreign minister and a Politburo member between 1992 and 1998.

;

;It is a sharp departure from party protocol and precedent, reflecting the urgency for the top leadership to stabilise the situation that has become a huge embarrassment for China's foreign affairs and a political crisis for Xi in his unprecedented third term.

;

;Observers said that both Qin's removal, which made him China's shortest-serving foreign minister, and the reappointment of Wang, who was foreign minister during Xi's first two terms, as his successor were unprecedented.

;

;While details about the nature of the sudden reshuffle remain scant, they noted the announcement was deliberately vague, raising questions about Qin's fate, which may yet to be decided.

;

;Wang, the director of the Office of the Central Foreign Affairs Commission, has been standing in during Qin's absence over the past few weeks.

;

;“The fact that Wang is picked to replace Qin as the country's new foreign minister in the middle of a major personnel crisis in mainland politics says a lot about Wang's close ties with the top leader,” said Alfred Wu, an associate professor at the Lee Kuan Yew School of Public Policy in Singapore.

;

;Apart from reinforcing Wang's status as the country's highest-ranking diplomat, it also underlined the veteran diplomat “remains Xi's most trusted foreign policy aide to oversee foreign affairs”, Wu said.

;

;Say no to 'digital iron curtain', China's Wang Yi tells Brics security officials

;

;Wang, who turns 70 in October, was promoted to the Politburo, the party's top echelon of power, at the Communist Party's national congress last year.

;

;He has been attending a series of diplomatic activities including the Brics gathering under way in South Africa and meetings with former US secretaries of state Henry Kissinger and John Kerry in China last week.

;

;The decision to remove Qin from his post was made at a special session of the National People's Congress Standing Committee, which took place one day after the Politburo convened.

;

;According to rules updated in June last year, the NPC Standing Committee holds a session once every two months, but in practice, usually holds them near the end of even-numbered months. An interim session for special cases can be scheduled by the committee's chairman.

;

;Qin's removal as foreign minister is in line with the Organic Law of the National People's Congress, which came into effect in March 2021. The rule empowers the Standing Committee rather than a national congress to appoint or remove from office some members of the State Council.

;

;But the brief announcement by state media suggested the top legislature made no decision to remove Qin as state councillor, a position that ranks above a cabinet minister.

;

;Analysts said the move was rather unusual, considering the NPC Standing Committee's removal in 2018 of Yang Jing, a top assistant to former premier Li Keqiang, as both state councillor and secretary general of the cabinet.

;

;Qin was last seen in public during a meeting of senior diplomats from Russia, Vietnam and Sri Lanka on June 25, according to China's foreign ministry.

;

;When asked on Tuesday before the official announcement about who would take on Qin's responsibilities, foreign ministry spokeswoman Mao Ning said: “I can tell you this, China's diplomatic affairs or work on the front is being smoothly advanced.”

;

;But Beijing's secretive handling of the drama has raised questions about the Chinese government's opaque decision-making process and increased confusion and mistrust in the West.

;

;Last week British Foreign Secretary James Cleverly postponed a planned trip to Beijing scheduled for the end of this month, citing Qin's prolonged absence from public view.

;

;Qin was also scheduled to meet the European Union's foreign policy chief, Josep Borrell, early this month, but Beijing abruptly cancelled the trip, saying Qin was not available.

;

;In the absence of details about what led to Qin's removal, Wu said the reshuffle had yet again underlined a lack of transparency in mainland politics.

;

;“The saga has been a big embarrassment for China, which has exposed the non-transparency nature of China's close decision-making,” he said.

;

;Wu said the sage occurred at a bad time for China as it tried to ease tensions with the United States and its allies and reboot foreign business confidence in the country.

;

;Zhiqun Zhu, an international relations professor at Bucknell University, said Wang's reappointment was aimed at stabilising the situation and offering assurances about the continuity of China's foreign policy.

;

;Qin was considered to be part of a new generation of rising Chinese diplomats, who were mostly born after 1963 and went on to complete formal education without interruption after the end of the Cultural Revolution.

;

;Owing to his close ties with Xi, Qin rose rapidly through the ranks – from ministry spokesman and deputy foreign minister in charge of protocol and European affairs to the country's second-ranking diplomat.

;

;Qin, who was nicknamed “a fighter” when he was a spokesman, was appointed China's ambassador to the United States in July 2021, and 17 months later was elevated to foreign minister, and then state councillor in March.

;Hong Kong should not take a hard line on “soft resistance” to the government if it only involved opposing views or “wrong opinions” about mainland China, a leading legal academic said on Tuesday.

;

;Albert Chen Hung-yee, a Hong Kong University law professor and former Basic Law Committee member, was speaking on Tuesday, a day after Secretary for Security Chris Tang Ping-keung said the government had to take “full action” against soft resistance against authorities.

;

;“So soft resistance … my own view is that the government should use its own means to counteract what it considers to be the wrong view of history, China or whatever, instead of using the law to do so,” Chen said at a discussion panel at the Foreign Correspondents' Club (FCC).

;

;Chen admitted he did not know how soft resistance would be defined, but said the general legal principle was that criminal law should not be used to police people's speech or thoughts just because the authorities disliked them.

;

;He told the Post after the FCC discussion that, instead of using the national security law or sanctions in Article 23 of the Basic Law, the government could use alternative methods, such as education in schools, government-sponsored programmes and cultural activities.

;

;But a spokesman for the Security Bureau on Tuesday said that the government remained committed to cracking down on “soft resistance” and there was no room for making compromise when it came to national security.

;

;The spokesman insisted the 2019 social unrest was fuelled and worsened by media, art and culture mobilised to stir up trouble.

;

;“One of the reasons was that some people made use of the media, art and culture as a means of soft resistance to incite others to hate the central authorities, Hong Kong government and law enforcers and to agitate for the use of violence and abet others to commit crimes,” he said.

;

;The spokesman added that even rumours could be a form of soft resistance.

;

;“It is to create contradiction and incite Hong Kong people to hate the central government and Hong Kong government, which could result in social unrest and thus threaten national security,” he said.

;

;But the spokesman maintained the crackdown on “soft resistance” was not an attempt to control people's thoughts and highlighted that the national security law guaranteed rights and freedoms.

;

;The FCC panel talk was organised to mark the third anniversary of the introduction of the Beijing-imposed National Security Law.

;

;New threat as Hong Kong separatists adopt fresh approach, security chief warns

;

;The 2020 legislation criminalised acts of secession, subversion, terrorism and collusion with foreign forces, with a maximum penalty of life imprisonment.

;

;Executive Council member and Senior Counsel Ronny Tong Ka-wah, another speaker, said Tang was only making a political statement and there was no need to overreact.

;

;“It is very dangerous to confuse law with politics,” Tong said.

;

;“There is no offence called soft resistance and there is no such thing [in the law].

;

;“You will only be convicted if you have the criminal intent to break the law.这里没有这样的法律。这是政治谈话。 He was just saying 'don't make trouble'.”

;

;Willy Fu Kin-chi, a director of Beijing's semi-official think tank the Chinese Association of Hong Kong and Macau Studies, agreed there was no legal definition of “soft resistance.”

;

;But Fu, also a law professor, warned that did not mean it could not be dealt with under the provisions of the national security law.

;

;“Soft resistance is a general term referring to the resistance without violence, for example, inciting people to commit crimes online or provoking citizens' hatred against the central government, the Hong Kong government, or the police,” Fu said.

;

;Hong Kong leader vows to win public trust with concrete actions and results

;

;Legislator Paul Tse Wai-chun appealed to the government to take a more relaxed approach to enforcement.

;

;“You simply can't control people's minds. After we have got rid of the major national security threats, perhaps it is time for us to take a more lenient approach,” Tse said.

;

;He sparked the debate over “soft resistance” after he said in an interview that the government should guard against “generalising” the concept of national security when tackling social problems.

;

;Chief Executive John Lee Ka-chiu warned of possible national security threats in the city in a recent interview with the Post.

;

;He said that China faced “attacks” for political reasons and there had been “soft resistance” in Hong Kong in a bid to “cause destructions”.

;

;Lee said a recent attempt to disrupt the city's organ donor register was a form of sabotage.

;

;There was a large increase in withdrawal applications from the register after the government announced plans to set up a cross-border donation scheme.

;

;More than 2,900 applications involved people who had never registered as organ donors or who made more than one withdrawal request.

;

;Zheng Yanxiong, the director of Beijing's liaison office in Hong Kong, said in June that there were “different forms of soft resistance” that continued to cause conflict and stoke hatred of the central and city governments through the internet and media.
